intro: Dipteracanthus drummondianus, commonly known as the Drummond's dipteracanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils and thrives in shaded to partially sunny conditions. Its leaves are leathery and dark green, while its flowers range in color from white to pink, adding ornamental value to gardens. It is often cultivated for its aesthetic appeal and ability to thrive in humid, woodland environments.
